isis.stitle: GENERAL INSTRUMENT ELECTRONIC PROGRAMMABLE SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER - TEST 6 - SENSOR OUTPUT VOLTAGE TEST (AT SENSOR)

svcproc.title: TEST 6 - SENSOR OUTPUT VOLTAGE TEST (AT SENSOR)
svcproc.para: This test checks for proper voltage output at the sensor. Improper sensor adjustment will cause low or no voltage condition.

caution.para: Use a voltmeter with sufficient meter lead lengths to avoid contact with rotating shaft or vehicle wheels.

item.para: To test speedometer sensor rear axles are to be on floor stands and transmission In high gear as in TEST 4.
To test tachometer wheels will be blocked, vehicle park set and transmission will be in neutral as in TEST 4.
This test requires the use of an AC voltmeter.

svcproc.para: Refer to Figure 18 for this test.

figure.caption: Sensor Output Voltage Test (AC) At Sensor

step1.para: Set AC voltmeter on 0-10 scale. Disconnect sensor unit lead from vehicle harness. Connect meter leads across sensor unit connector terminals.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or property damage pay strict attention to the following: Should it be necessary to operate the rear wheels (with engine power) with the vehicle stationary and the rear wheels raised from the ground, first disengage the front axle; otherwise the driving front axle will pull the vehicle off its support. Parking brakes should be applied when the transmission and the transfer case have been left in the neutral position with the engine running or not running.
Do not use a jack when working under a vehicle. It may give way, causing the vehicle to fall and injure you. Always use floor stands to support the vehicle.

step1.para: Checking Speedometer Sensor - With vehicle rear axles on floor stands and transmission in neutral, start engine at run at IDLE speed.
Checking Tachometer Sensor - With wheels blocked, vehicle park brake set and transmission in neutral, start engine and run at IDLE speed.
Read Volt meter. Voltage should be 2.0 volts minimum.
If NO voltage, replace and adjust sensor, then retest to verify.
If LOW voltage, adjust sensor and retest to verify. If adjustment fails to correct low voltage condition, replace sensor and retest to verify.
When defects corrected and verified in TEST 6, return to TEST 3 and rerun. If TEST 3 is not successful correct defect in vehicle wire harness between instrument panel connection and sensor.
